titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr Woodward brought me this morning from Mr Slade a slip from an English Newspaper, of 10. July. containing Articles of intelligence from America to 13 June, which reduce it almost to a certainty that War against England was declared within a week from that time. Mr Harris afterwards sent me the Morning Chronicle from 4 to 10 July— After dinner I rode to Kammenoi-Ostrof, and walked home— Returning, I met Mr Harris and walked with him. Notice had been given yesterday from the police to the Inhabitants of the City that the Emperor being expected this day, in case of his arrival they must illuminate their houses— Mr Harris told me he had just come from the square of the Cazan Church, where a great crowd of People were assembled, waiting for the Emperor, that being the first place to which he would go, to attend a religious service.— He did not however arrive—

2. The Emperor was expected all this day but did not arrive. I rode to Kammenoi-Ostroff, and walked in Count Strogonoff’s Gardens, with the Ladies— I also walked home— Met Mr Plummer on the Quay. The Evening was uncommonly fine; and remarkably warm. I read the Sermons 3. 4. and 5. Vol. 8. of the English Preacher— On the spiritual Nature of the Christian Worship— Sterne’s Vindication of human Nature; and on the peculiar infamy of vice in an enlightened age— I likewise read some pages in Watts’s Logic; on the doctrine of Prejudices—which occasioned the reflection how excessively difficult it is to divest one’s self of prejudices; and how much more difficult still to discard prejudices, without falling into indifference with regard to important truth. I believe the best guard against prejudice is a frequent examination of our opinions, and a cool estimate of the arguments opposed to them— You must as Cicero says identify yourself in imagination, first with your adversary and then with your judge—and above all you must have resolution to abide by the result even if it should be adverse to your preconceived opinions. The victory over prejudice is a Conquest of one’s self.— It is better than to be the ruler of a City.

3. The Emperor arrived here this morning about two O’Clock— I suppose because this is the Empress-Mother’s name day; and one illumination answered for both Events— I walked before Breakfast in the Summer Gardens; and in coming round the Boulevard, I perceived the Imperial flag, flying over the Palace, which first gave me notice of the Emperor’s return— I wrote a long letter and was dissatisfied with it, so that I determined not to send it— Mr Lewis and Mr Willing called upon me— After dinner we rode to Kammenoi-Ostroff, and I walked home— The illumination was very general throughout the City. The weather is at high Summer heat.

4. Morning Visits from Captain Boit and Mr Harris— Captain Boit told me he should be ready to go down to Cronstadt next Monday; and requested me to procure for him a Courier’s Passport, for which I promised to apply— Mr Harris mentioned that the Emperor yesterday announced to his Court that the peace with England had been signed— In the Evening the Ladies and Charles went to the Theatre— I walked in the Summer-Gardens— Mr Redwood and Mr Kimball were afterwards here.

5. Bathed and walked in the Summer Gardens this morning before Breakfast— I attended from Noon, untill 4 in the afternoon, at the sale of the Chevalier de Bray’s furniture— There I met Don Francisco Colombi and Mr Zea, who informed me that Count Wittgenstein had totally defeated Marshal Oudinot, with great slaughter, and had taken his baggage, Artillery, and three thousand prisoners.— In Spain too he said all was going on well, and Lord Wellington was at Salamanca.— After dinner I had a visit from Claude Gabriel, the Black Man in the Emperor’s service who went to America last Summer for his wife and children, and who is now come back with them— He complains of having been very ill-treated in America, and that he was obliged to lay aside his superb dress, and Sabre which he had been ordered to wear, but which occasioned people to insult and even beat him.— Count St: Julien the late Austrian Minister, had a fancy for appearing in public here in the Vienna fashion— So he drove about the streets last Winter in a sleigh of a different appearance from those here used— It was a sort of Phaeton-body, hung upon runners, perhaps six feet high, and with clusters of sleigh-bells at the saddle-place of the two horses— He drove himself, with a footman carrying an enormous muff behind him on the sleigh— Although this is perhaps the spot of the globe, where varieties of dress, and of modes of appearing in public, are most common, and where they of course excite the least attention, there was yet something so ludicrously fantastical in this anomaly of Count St: Julien’s Sleigh, that he made himself the laughter of the Court and City by it. I was once mentioning to him how dangerous it was to appear in the Streets of London, in any mode or dress different from those to which the eyes of the people are accustomed— “Then I suppose[”] said he, [“]my Traineau would make a Riot there—[”] I told him I questioned whether he would ever have occasion to use it a second time in that City— It was said that he had asked the Emperor Alexander’s permission to exhibit this rarity about the town, and that the Emperor Alexander answered him, that he had not the slightest objection—but added; if the children in the Streets, should throw stones at it, I hope, Monsieur le Comte, you will not be surprized— There was so much sound sense in this remark, that I know not how the idea had not occurred to the Emperor, when he ordered Claud Gabriel to wear in public his magnificent gala Court dress, when he should arrive in America— After wearing them once at Providence and once at Boston, he says he was obliged to hide them; and he looks as if even that wearing had cost him five or six of his front teeth. He says however he told the Emperor that he had been well treated, and that he had worn the dress all the time.— I Rode with the Ladies and Charles to Kammenoi-Ostrof, and walked home alone— Captain Groves had been this morning to ask my advice whether he should sail, under the prospect of War, between the United States and England— He is here with a vessel of Mr Gray’s; and all ready to depart— I advised him to wait for further information— Mr Proud called three or four times to see me in the course of the day, but I was not at home— In the Evening I received a Note from him informing me that he had the Official Declaration of War by the American Government against Great-Britain; which was brought him by Express from Gothenburg— Mr Smith afterwards came in and had heard the Declaration was issued on the 18th: of June; two days after the debate in Parliament, upon which the British Orders in Council were revoked. This day commences the fourth year since we embarked at Charleston to come to Russia.

6. I had this morning a succession of visitors— Mr Harris— Captain Boit and Captain Seaman, and Mr Woodward and Captain Groves; all much perplexed in consequence of this American Declaration of War. I wrote a Note to Mr Proud, inviting him to dine with us;— I attended again at the sale of the Chevalier de Bray’s furniture, and made a few further purchases. Mr Zea took me home in his Carriage— There was a Court and Te Deum, on account of Wittgensteins victory over Oudinot, but the foreign Ministers were not invited to attend.
Mr Proud dined with us, and brought with him the New-York Commercial Advertiser of 22 June, containing the Message from the President of the United States to Congress communicating the sequel of the Correspondence between Mr Monroe, and Mr Foster, and recommending a Declaration of War— The Report of the Committee of Foreign Relations upon this Message, also recommending an immediate appeal to arms— The Act, declaring War, approved 18 June—the Proclamation of the President, founded upon the Act of Congress—and the yeas and Nays in both Houses upon the Act. 79 to 49 in the House of Representatives; and 19 to 13. in the Senate— Two Senators, Mr Bradley and Mr Whitesides absent— Minturn and Champlin sent off a Pilot-Boat from New-York to Gothenburg, with this Intelligence, for the purpose of securing their property there and here from British Capture on this occasion— The vessel arrived at Gothenburg 23. July, and Mr Proud, who is an agent of Minturn and Champlin received the paper by Express from that place. I received also from Count Soltykoff, a letter from Mr Speyer, enclosing Copy of one from Mr Connell to him mentioning the arrival of this Pilot-Boat at Gothenburg— In the Evening I rode out with the Ladies and Charles, on the road to Czarsko-Zelo. I walked round through the Summer Gardens home— I found a general illumination of the City again; on account of Wittgenstein’s victory— We were up untill between one and two in the Morning.— Heat Excessive.

7. Bathed this morning, and walked with Charles, before Breakfast.— Attended again at the Chevalier de Bray’s sale— Being the last day— I purchased only one trifling Article— The Original Cost of furnishing this house was about 50000 Rubles— The Sales may have amounted to about 25000.— On the whole the Articles sold well— There was neither table-linen, Plate, nor kitchen furniture— The sale was much aided, by several fugitive families from Riga, and the invaded Provinces, obliged to take up their residence here, and wanting furniture— The News of another Russian Victory, by General Tormassoff, over the Saxon Troops was brought and circulated while the sale was going on. It finished about four O’Clock and I walked home. While we were at dinner we had one of the most sudden and violent thunder-gusts that I ever witnessed— The weather cleared up in the Evening— We rode out on the Wyburg road, and returned through Kammenoi-Ostrof— I walked home.

8. Morning visit from Captain Boit, and also from Mr Raimbert. Captain Boit concludes to go by land, and Captain Seaman goes with him— The Ladies and Mr Smith went this Evening to the Theatre— I rode out with Charles to Count Strogonoff’s Garden, and walked with him there— Sent him in from Kammenoi-Ostrof to the Theatre, and walked home. Captain Boit told me he had had some Conversation with Captain Bates, lately from Riga— The French it appears are again before that place.

9. I wrote a note this day to Count Soltykoff, requesting a Courier’s Passport for Captain Boit, who called upon me this morning, and again in the Evening— Rode after dinner round the Wyburg road and through Kammenoi-Ostrof home— I was prevented from walking, by a thunder-shower which came up, while we were out. There was a Te Deum at the Imperial Chapel this day, and in the Evening an Illumination of the City, on Account of General Tormassoff’s victory over a Corps of Saxons, at Kobrin— I read the Sermons 6 and 7. Vol. 8. of the English Preacher, on the natural grounds and measures of Charity, and on setting bounds to our desires— They are historical discourses, the first on the Story of Nabal’s affair with David, and the other on that of Elisha and the Shunamite— I read also a few pages of Watts’s Logic—still on the subject of prejudices— The excessive heat of the weather, disabled me from writing part of the day.

10. Mr Harris called upon me this morning, and expressed his fears that there had been a great Battle, and that the Russian army had been defeated— But upon further enquiry I found that the only foundation he had for this opinion was a report that the French were at Veliki-Luki, which does not at-all imply the defeat of either of the great Russian armies— I went to Mr Bezerra’s to inform him of the opportunity of writing by Captain Boit— He was not at home— I saw Madame Bezerra, and mentioned to her the opportunity; but she said Mr Bezerra was himself dispatching a Courier this Evening— I then went to the Hotel de l’Europe to ask of Mr Hochschild a Courier’s Passport from him, for Captain Boit, and to offer to send by him any dispatches that Mr Hochschild wished to transmit— He promised me the Passport. I found Mr Brandel with him; arrived last Evening from Toropetz; the last place, where Count Romanzoff had been— Count Löwenhielm had followed the Russian army to Witebsk, but Mr Brandel expects him back here soon— The Emperor and Count Romanzoff, Brandel says are shortly going away again— Probably to be nearer the armies— The Russian Head Quarters are at Smolensk— Platoff is arrived there; and the two great armies have so far formed their junction, that Count Romanzoff told Brandel this morning the two Generals, Barclai de Tolli, and Prince Bagration
had dined together.— Brandel had heard nothing of the Russian army’s being defeated— The Ladies spent the Evening with Madame Bezerra. I went with Charles to Count Strogonoff’s garden, and walked there— I also walked home; sending Charles from the Summer-Garden Bridge, to his mother at Madam Bezerra’s— Mr Woodward was likewise here this morning and has concluded to go to England, to obtain advice for his complaint.

11. Mr: Montreal, Mr Harris, Messrs: Saltus and Proud, Captain Boit, and Messrs: Delprat and Livingston called upon me this morning successively— Mr Montreal told me that the eldest of the two brothers Consolat had this morning received an order from the Police to quit the Country within eight days, and has permission to take the road to Sweden— Mr Harris came in much agitation; a similar order having been signified this morning to two Frenchmen residing in his house— The Abbé Fremont who is an Instructor to his nephew, and an old man who serves him as Cook— Mr Harris thought it was an infraction of the Law of Nations, and appeared inclined to make an affair of diplomatic remonstrance of it— But it was my opinion that neither a Consul, nor even a public Minister could protect foreigners in his house, not of his own Nation; and especially not of a Nation at War with that where he resides—from the police laws of the Country— There is indeed usually a good deal of indulgence on this subject in the practice of all Nations, in ordinary times, but every State must be the judge when its own interests require that this indulgence should be withdrawn— I did not think that in the present case, Mr Harris’s Consular Privilege, could extend to exempt frenchmen in his service, and residing in his house from the operations of the Police— Mr Saltus and Mr Proud came to enquire if I could procure from the Russian Government a Passport, for the Pilot-Boat which came from New-York, and brought the American Declaration of War against Great-Britain— They wish to send her home with Papers which may protect her from British Capture, which if she took dispatches from this Government to their Minister in America, they supposed a Russian Passport would do— Though doubtful whether this Government would grant such a Passport, I promised to apply for it.— I received the Passports both from Count Soltykoff, and from Mr Hochschild, for Captain Boit, and gave them to him, with my letters and dispatches— It was however so late before I received them, that he postponed his departure untill to-morrow morning— Mr Delprat came to introduce Mr Livingstone who arrived here a very few days since— I rode after dinner to Kammenoi-Ostrof, and walked home— The Ladies went to the Theatre.

12. I paid a visit this morning to Count Romanzoff, but he was not at home— I then called upon Count Soltykoff, and asked him if this Government would furnish a Passport for a vessel to carry dispatches directly to the United-States for me; and for the Russian Government itself if they wished to send any to their Minister in America— The Count said he thought it would not meet with much difficulty; but it was necessary for him to consult with the Minister of Commerce to whose Department it belonged; and he would give me an answer in a few days— I told him how our relations stood with regard to England— While I was with him the Duke de Serra-Capriola came in, and I left him with the Count— He was heretofore Ambassador from the king of the two Sicilies; but since the Peace of Tilsit, Murat has been acknowledged here in that capacity— Now the Duke’s character comes into operation and activity again. I called upon Mr Bezerra, and conversed with him about two hours— A Portuguese Officer came in while I was there; a deserter from the French army, who has entered the Russian service— He was accompanied by a Spanish Officer— The Emperor has received them very graciously and given them each fifty ducats— A packet was brought in from Count Soltykoff—letters for Mr Bezerra and the Courier d’Angleterre of 17. July containing the first three Bulletin’s from the French Army, on the commencement of the War with Russia. Also a Correspondence, containing the overtures of Peace from France to England, previous to this War— After I came home Mr Saltus and Mr Proud called upon me, to know the success of my application for the Passport— I mentioned to them what Count Soltykoff had said to me, and promised the definitive answer when I should receive it— In the Evening we rode out on the Peterhoff road and I walked home with Charles— My daughter Louisa is this day one year old.— 2 f 3 i— Charles 3 f 4 1/2 i.

13. Morning visits from Mr Raimbert, and from Mr Lewis and Mr Redwood— Received from Mr Beasley a letter of 24 July—with a London Courier of that date— The American Declaration of War was known there, by a Pilot-Boat, like the one that has arrived here. After dinner we rode to Kammenoi-Ostrof and I walked home— From this Night they begin to light the Streets of the City— On my return home I found Mr Plummer upon a visit— The Ladies lost their gowns— Stolen from the chamber next to my bed-chamber while they were riding out this morning— It being the first day of the Month, Russian Style, I was engaged part of the day, settling my monthly Accounts.

14. Mrs Adams and Catherine, the two Children, Mrs Helm the infant’s Nurse and Martha went with me to Oranienbaum. We left home at half past 9. in the morning, and precisely at Noon, stop’d at a house kept by an English woman Mrs Tringham, where we dined. The distance is thirty-five Versts, besides three to the Verst Stone within the City from which they begin their admeasurement. 25 English Miles; which our horses ran without once stopping to rest or to drink— We had four horses in a line; driven by the Coachman; and two leaders, by the Postilion— Seven persons, including the two children in the Coach— At Oranienbaum we went to see the Palace, with its Gardens, and appendant buildings, which though smaller and less magnificent than those of Peterhoff, command a finer prospect, and are kept in better condition. There is nothing however very remarkable to be seen in the Palaces.— The Series of artificial hillocks, which I believe was invented and constructed in the time of the Empress Elizabeth, is now totally decayed, and ruinous; so that without an explanation it would be impossible to conjecture what was its original intention. It was entire, though I believe no longer used when I saw it before in January 1782.— There are some indifferent paintings, in some of the Apartments, and in the choice of the subjects there appears a predilection for such as the Judgment of Paris, Venus and Adonis, Hercules and Omphala, Diana and Endymion, and the like— There is a Billiard Room wainscoted with the Nine Muses. Tables inlaid with Mosaic— Collections of old China, Japan vases and Dresden Porcelain— The most ingenious of which is a concert of monkies, in porcelain figures. Each figure with a different instrument and attitude; and all caricatures of the various kinds of affected Melomania. The furniture is all very old, and exhibits magnificence in all its stages of decay, from the mere change of fashion, to the perishing rags and tatters of crimson satin curtains and chair-covers— We dined about 4. O’Clock, and returned in about the same time we had taken to go. We reached the City before eight in the Evening, and I walked from the Fontanka home. The road as far as Peterhoff is entirely plain; but from thence to Oranienbaum there are several hills and dales— The view of Cronstadt on the opposite side of the gulph is most pleasant between the two places.— The villages are both small and mean.

15. I had a morning visit from Mr Lewis, and one in the Evening from Mr Kimball— Walked with Charles before Breakfast, and with Catherine and him in the Botanical Garden after dinner— They are organizing the new armament for the defence of the Country and the Nobility of the Governments of St: Petersbourg, and of Moscow, have given one Man in ten of their peasants, for the army— I saw many of them this Morning, just in from the Country, with the one horse waggons, and the families of the recruits taking leave of them.— The number of volunteers is very great, and if they find it as easy to organize and discipline them as they find it to raise the men, there is little danger for the Country to apprehend from the invasion, under which it now suffers.— Mrs Adams weaned the child.

16. Mr Woodward came this morning, and informed me of his intention to go to morrow to Cronstadt, intending to embark there in one of the vessels about to sail for Sweden—to proceed thence to England, and return home before winter, to Boston— I wrote a short letter to go by him, but I have been several days unwell; enough to be disqualified for much writing.— I rode as usual after dinner to Kammenoi-Ostrof, and walked home— Read Sermons 8 and 9. Vol. 8. of the English Preacher— On the Causes and Consequences of intellectual darkness— It includes the doctrine of prejudices, which the preacher descants upon, almost in the same method, as Watts in his Logic— Of this I likewise read a few pages.— Mrs Adams very unwell, in the process of weaning her infant.

17. Mr Woodward went down to Cronstadt this morning to embark; I gave him two letters for America; and sent one for London, to him in the Evening.— I had also visits from Mr Plummer with Captain Bates, and from Mr Livingston with Mr Dimond— Mr Livingston wishes for a Courier’s Passport to go by the Pilot-Boat— Rode out, and walked in from the Country as usual— Mr Proud was here in the Evening. Mrs Adams quite unwell.

18. Bathed and walked in the Summer Gardens before Breakfast. Morning visit from Mr Harris, and in the Evening from Mr Redwood.— Received the Duke de Serra Capriola’s Card as Minister Plenipotentiary from the king of the two Sicilies. Rode to Kammenoi-Ostrof, after dinner— Walked in the Summer Gardens, and home with Charles.— Mr Harris mentioned to me that the Abbe de Fremont and the Cook, who had been ordered to quit the Country, though residing in his house, have since been taken off from the list of banishment, and are permitted to remain— Mr Consolat has received the same permission— But great numbers of others, who had been passed over before, have now received orders to go. There seems to be no settled principle upon which the exclusions are directed; but the matter is left to the daily humours and discretion of the Police— Charles is this day five years old. 3 f. 4 1/2 i.

19. Mr Montréal called upon me this morning, and complained that Mr Woodward had gone away without adjusting their Account with Mr Gray, or making suitable provision for the payment of the balance due them— Mr Consolat was going down to Cronstadt to persuade or compel him to make an arrangement with them, or to stop him by legal process— At Mr Montreal’s request I gave him a letter to Mr Woodward, recommending to him to comply with their reasonable requests, and to do what I had understood him before he went away was really done already— Mr Livingston came, respecting his Passport; for which I wrote Count Soltykoff a Note; at the same time renewing the request for a Passport for the vessel— I was obliged to dismiss from my service Thomas Baker, who has served me several months as Steward; and also Catherine the Maid-Servant— His vices are women, and drinking— The natural consequence of which is stealing of every kind— Besides considerable losses of all the provisions of the house, within the last week many articles of cloathing have been stolen— This having led to enquiries, I went to his Room, and found a woman there, whom he has kept for Months, and introduced into the house contrary to a positive prohibition from me. I dismissed him immediately— And am now to try another— I walked, morning and Evening.

20. Dined at the Chevalier Bezerra’s—with Count Soltykoff, the Duke de Serra-Capriola, and his son, Count Maistre, Mr Zea, Counts Lieven and Orloff, Mr Hochschild, Lord Tyrconnel, and Mr Benkendorf— It was a dinner given upon occasion of the Duke de Serra-Capriola’s resuming the character of Minister Plenipotentiary from the king of the two Sicilies— Having received the invitation by a written Note, I was doubtful whether it was a full dress, or a frock dinner (a matter of no small consequence in diplomatic etiquette) and sent this morning to enquire— Mr Bezerra sent me word to come in frock, but by the mistake of his Servant or of mine, I was told it was a uniform (small full dress) dinner— I went in uniform, was the first person there, found Mr Bezerra in frock, and astonished to see me full dressed. The Duke and his Son, and Count Maistre however came in the same Manner— Count Soltykoff, and the other guests excepting the military persons were in frocks— Count Orloff, in Nankin Pantaloons, the most complete undress in which it is decent to appear.— Mr Bezerra was much mortified, under the idea, that a full dress dinner, implies more State and Magnificence in the reception and Entertainment than he intended— But a written or printed invitation by the usage here implies a full dress, unless expressed to be in frock— So the Duke and Count Maistre had understood it, and though I had doubted, and sent to enquire, the answer I received had fixed me in mistake— The Dinner was agreeable; the Duke being in high-Spirits, and as always full of pleasant Conversation— Admiral Bentinck an English negotiating Officer lately arrived was invited, but sent an excuse— He is going this Night with the Emperor, to Abo; where, or in that vicinity His Majesty is to have a personal interview with the Prince Royal of Sweden— Count Löwenhielm, and Mr Brandel went off this Morning. Lord Tyrconnel is the Secretary to the English Embassy; arrived at Riga, and went on to the Emperor’s Head Quarters, whence he returned here— The Ambassador Lord Cathcart has not yet arrived— Mr Hochschild told me that Madame de Stael was here, at the Hotel de l’Europe; going to England— Count Soltykoff, told me that he should send me the Courier’s Passport I had asked for Mr Livingston, but having no occasion to send dispatches to America, he could not give the Passport for the Vessel.— Count Liewen and the Duke de Serra-Capriola, amused themselves much at the expence of Count and Countess Goltz of Berlin, and of Prince Kurakin late Russian Ambassador at Paris; who is still detained there, or near that City, by ill-health. After I came home we rode out to our last Summer’s Residence, and I walked back. The Emperor passed by us on a Droshky, upon the Summer-Garden Bridge— I had not seen him before since his return from the army.— Dr: Galloway came this Evening to see our child who is again very severely attacked with the Dysentery.

21. The Child was extremely ill, all last Night; and the whole of this day— In the Evening, the violence of the fever, abated in some degree. Dr: Galloway called to see her in the morning; but was going to Gatchina, not to return, untill to-morrow Night. He left a note for Dr Simpson, requesting his attendance to the child, to be sent to him to-morrow morning, if she should be no better. I wrote as much as I could in the course of the day— Walked in the Summer Gardens in the Morning— Rode to Kammenoi-Ostrof after dinner, and walked through the Summer-Gardens home, with Charles— Mr Livingston came and received his Passport, and Mr Kimball brought me some papers respecting the Sally, an American vessel, condemned by a Russian prize-Court, at Corfu; upon which I could not do any thing; and recommended to Mr Kimball to leave the papers with Mr Harris.

22. The Child is yet very ill, but has the fever and other symptoms less violent than yesterday. I called upon Mr Fisher before Breakfast— At Dr Galloway’s recommendation Mrs Adams has begun to Nurse the child again— Mr Livingston called and took my letters and dispatches— Mr Montreal called, and brought me a letter from Mr Woodward, who is embarked at Cronstadt— Mr Montreal complains of him very much, and even suspects him of not doing Justice to his employer Mr Gray— I hope he is mistaken. But there is something so infectious to pecuniary integrity in the atmosphere of St: Petersburg, that there is not one young man in a thousand, who can escape its pestilential influence— We rode out after dinner on the Moscow road; and I walked home with Charles. We had an Evening visit from the Chevalier Bezerra and his Lady.

23. The Child was apparently so much better yesterday and last Evening, that we did not send for Dr: Simpson, expecting that Dr Galloway would have returned last Night— But she had a very restless Night, and this Morning the violent symptoms returned with others yet more alarming— We sent for Dr Galloway, and received for answer that he was gone out of town for four or five days— We sent for Simpson—he was gone out of town to dinner, and was to return at Midnight— In the Evening about eleven, I sent the Carriage to wait at his house untill he should return, with a request that he would come immediately to see the Child. An hour afterwards the Carriage came back without him— He had returned home, and sent word he could not come this Night, but would come in the Morning to-morrow— I went then to him myself, and found him in bed— I told him the Circumstances of the Child’s situation, and prevailed upon him to come with me and see her.— He immediately prescribed an emetic and other things— I was up with her untill between two and three in the Morning—Mrs Adams untill four— I read the Sermons 10 and 11. Vol. 8. of the English Preacher; on the duty of Resignation, and against profaneness— Also several Sections in Watts— My Mind was too much agitated and absorbed by the Condition of my Child, to read with suitable improvement— The Sermon upon Resignation is by Leed, and adapted to my feelings at this time— Resignation, I know to be a duty, and the considerations upon which the preacher urges it are just and forcible— But it is a painful duty; and which it requires aid from above to be able to fulfill— Profaneness is a vice without a motive— And as it was once fashionable among all Classes of People it was more to be preached against formerly than it need be now— Like Drunkenness it is now principally confined to the uneducated Classes of Society.

24. Mr Kimball called on me this morning for a new Passport for Mr Baylies; who goes to embark to-morrow— Mr Kimball himself does not go so soon— Mr Plummer was here in the Evening, with young Norman; for a Passport which I gave him.— There was a succession of heavy thunder-showers all day— The Evening was clear, and we rode to the Kammenoi-ostrof-Bridge and back. The Child has had more favourable symptoms this day; though yet dangerously ill.— The part of the day in which I could give attention to any thing, I was attempting to arrange an Inventory of Furniture and household Articles; the want of which I have experienced— And a method for which, I would prepare.

25. I walked with Charles before Breakfast— Rode with him alone to Kammenoi-Ostrof after dinner, and walked home, from the Summer Gardens. I wrote scarcely any thing, and read very little. Nelson was here this morning, and gave me the account of his Condition, in his present Service— He is not satisfied with it, and would be glad to change it, if he could obtain his dismission— He observed the first years treatment to be better than those that followed— The Child was apparently better last Night and the first part of this day, but in the Evening was again quite ill.

26. Dr: Galloway again returned and visited the Child, who is yet extremely ill.— He and Dr: Simpson both recommend that she should as soon as possible be taken for some days or weeks into the Country.— We have been making an enquiries, if a place could be found in the vicinity of the City where we could engage three or four rooms for a short time— Mrs Krehmer was here this morning and mentioned to Mrs Adams that there was such a tenement, two or three doors from their Country-residence, and after dinner I went out with Catherine and Charles and looked over it. We first called at Mr Krehmer’s, where we met Mr Wilson, Mr Hoggart, and Mr Gisborne, who is to marry Mr Krehmer’s daughter— There were two places at which we looked, and either of which we were offered for a Month— I fixed upon one of them, for Mrs Adams to see herself to-morrow— It was dark when we returned home. Dr: Galloway visited the Child again this Evening.— The Grand-Duke Constantine arrived at 4. O’Clock this Morning, and went to join the Emperor at Abo, this Night.— Rumours are in Circulation that the Russian armies have suffered a great defeat near Smolensk— The Condition of my child has scarcely left me the power to attend to other objects with the interest which they ought to excite— I walked this morning with Charles, on the new Canal, behind the Riding-School of the Horse Guards— Charles began reading Berquin Vol. 3.

27. This morning I walked to the Shops, intending to purchase some articles there, but found them all shut for a Holiday— It is the last of the small lent of 15 days from the first of August. The Child has been this day a little better.— Mrs Adams went out to look at the houses we had seen yesterday, and chose the same we had fixed upon— Mr Harris called on me, and brought me a letter from Mr Beasley, at London, announcing an Embargo upon American vessels in England, and orders to the British Navy to take and carry in all they can find. This Evening I rode to Kammenoi-Ostroff with Catherine and Charles, and walked from the summer-gardens home.

28. Morning visits from Mr Montreal and Mr Lewis— After dinner I rode out to Ochta, called at the lodging taken for Mrs Adams and the Child, and also a few minutes at Mr Krehmer’s— I walked home, and on the quay overtook Mr Harris— Nothing is published respecting the late Battles at and near Smolensk; of which there are now said to have been four— The reports concerning them are exceedingly various.— The letters from the Officers assert the advantage to have been constantly on the Russian side, and wonder why the Commander in Chief Barclai de Tolli ordered the retreat— There is now an extraordinary clamour against that General. Prince Bagration is not in much better credit— General Kutuzoff, who was made a Prince after the Turkish Peace, last week was appointed Commander in Chief of all the active armies; and left the City last Saturday night to go and take the Command— The want of a single head, to the Russian Military force is a great misfortune to the Country.

29. Much of the day was employed in arrangements for Mrs Adams’s visit to the Country, with Catherine, the two Children, the Nurse, a Maid-Servant, and two Men-Servants— We Sent out this morning a Man, with a Boat-load of Beds, Bedding, and other necessary Articles— After dinner we went out there ourselves— I walked from the Summer-Gardens home.— The Child we hope is better, but extremely weak, and very slowly recovering.— The physicians do not expect she will be essentially better, untill the teeth come through, the breeding and cutting of which they think the occasion of her disease.— I finished the reperusal of Watts’s Logic. 26 years after I first read it— I hope to recur to it again, more than once with my Children.

30. Mrs: Adams went into the Country with the infant and her Nurse, before dinner— Catherine and Charles went after dinner, and I went with them— Pierre Ouvré had staid there last Night; and the House-maid Marie had been sent out this morning— I have taken the place for a Month.— Mrs Krehmer and Mr Fisher came in while I was there— I returned into the City for the Night.— Part of the day was employed in the arrangements of removal for part of the family— I read Sermons 12 and 13. Vol 8 of the English Preacher, upon Intemperance, and on the inefficacy of a Death-bed repentance.— The first considers intemperance in the most limited sense of the word, as synonimous with drunkenness;—a vice so rooted into the Constitution of human Nature that probably no preaching, will altogether reform it— In the progress of social refinement the wealthy and distinguished classes of Society, for the most part shake it off, but often only to exchange one species of intemperance for another— Temperance in its most extensive sense is a rare and heroic Virtue.— On Death-bed Repentance, I heard twice at Washington a Sermon by Mr M’Cormick, which I thought contained the whole of the Argument— There are however some additional considerations, in this Discourse; and particularly some ingenious suggestions to take the case of the penitent thief crucified with Jesus Christ out of the general rule, without affecting its universality.— I also read the first Book of Paley’s Moral and Political Philosophy.

31. I went out this morning to Ochta, to see my family there, and again after dinner with Mr Smith— The distance is about 7. Miles. The Child appears to be a little better; but still very weak— I received letters from Mr Gray of Boston, and his Son W. R. dated June 24. with an account of the declaration of War— They were sent by a dispatch Boat, which sailed from Boston for the same purpose as the Champlin had been dispatched from New-York— But the Boston Boat was taken and carried into Norway. I had also a letter from Mr Forbes at Copenhagen, enclosing one from Mr Erving at Paris.

Day. Varied from that of the last Month only by the incidents in my family. The dismissal of my Steward Thomas Baker, has brought upon me again a most irksome load of the minutest trifles of housekeeping; and they are now doubled by the removal of half the family into the Country— The man whom I took in the room of Thomas, is quite incompetent to the situation, and I must go through another change— The illness of my child occurring precisely at the same time adds to my difficulties; and other Circumstances which I would not commit to paper, increase my perplexities and seem to baffle every precaution of Prudence— The mind absorbed by the perpetual recurrence of these disgusting trifles, has neither leisure nor tranquility for attention to objects worthy to engage it— I read little, and scarcely write at-all.
